title: Will casualties from the Turkey-PKK conflict exceed 125 in any month from August through November 2017, according to the International Crisis Group?
preds: Perversely, the ICG tracker still says "last updated on 22 November", still has the prior month data unchanged from 11 November, but now also has initial figures for November: 26 PKK + 13 security forces = 39 total deaths (ie. more than October already). The only thing that might alter my "lock-it-in" forecast is if the ICG updates the October figures before GJO close the books in about 8 hours.

Since my last update, there has been a screeching halt in the number of deaths reported in the media: only 4 more deaths reported between 18 November and now.  That brings the total number of reported deaths only up to pretty much smack on 125.  I had thought that we were heading for 150 or more. DECREASE probability of November exceeding 125 reported deaths: 0.80 -> 0.40
DECREASE probability that, if November exceeds 125 deaths, 126 of those deaths will be confirmed by 29 Dec: 0.10 -> 0.03
Highest month so far was September with 80 casualties. October numbers may not be complete yet.

ICG conflict tracker has been updated!  So now looks possible there will be an early-December, mid-December, and late-December update before the question is adjudicated. However, the actual confirmed death counts for each month (including October) have _not_ increased since the counts published on 11 November.  Perhaps this is a typo, and updated figures will be provided in the next day or so. Watch this space ... ********************************

All my calculations to date have assumed that November will get only two "bites" at the ICG website: the end-November update, and the mid-December update.  If there is an update in early December, then an update in late December (before the 29th), then it becomes _much_ more likely that a bloody November would actually surpass 125 confirmed deaths.

I've had to totally rejig the model here.  I've under-estimated the delay in PKK deaths being confirmed by the ICG.  I'll need to refine the figures once I get more data about just how delayed the confirmation of PKK deaths are and, indeed, how many PKK deaths reported in the media _never_ get confirmed (at least not in the 4mth timeframe of this forecast). So, for each month, "What is the probability that total deaths reported in the media will exceed 125?"  It is almost inconceivable that the ICG will confirm more deaths in a month than there were deaths reported in the media. Then that probability needs to be modified by the question, "What is the probability that ICG will confirm enough of those deaths to exceed 125?"  This probability will be influenced by:
(a) the total number of reported deaths (if there are 300 deaths reported in the media in October, that is different to only 130 being reported);
(b) what proportion of those reported deaths are PKK (if there are 140 total deaths reported in October, it will be more significant if 100 of those 140 are civilian/security forces deaths that are easily confirmed, than if 100 of those 140 are PKK who might never be confirmed); and
(c) how many weeks are left before the 29th of December (140 deaths reported in September are more likely to "get over the line" than 140 deaths reported in November). At the moment, for August, the probability that the reported deaths exceeded 125 I'd put at about 0.20.  There are too many rubbery figures around "neutralisation" and "inside -v- outside Turkey".   _If_ the reported deaths exceeded 125, the likelihood that ICG will confirm it is about 0.20.  There is plenty of time for the current figure (20 PKK deaths) to grow (70-100 reported).  OTOH, the total reported deaths only _just_ exceeds 125, so pretty much every reported PKK death would need to be confirmed ... which is unlikely.  Then again, it happened in July (eventually)! Overall, about a 4% chance that August will eventually exceed 125 deaths. September off to a slow start so far: only 15-20 deaths reported in the first week.  Needs to average 40 deaths/wk for the remainder of the month to reach 125.

For June, July, and August, Turkish media figures and ICG's figures for civilian and security forces deaths are concordant.  PKK deaths are quite divergent.  For example, excluding "neutralisations": June:  About 100 reported in media; only 41 confirmed by ICG.
July:  About 55 reported in media; 55 confirmed by ICG.

So it is not even clear that increased activity reported in contemporaneous Turkish media reports correlate with increased ICG-confirmed PKK deaths.  I'll see if I can chase up some data suggesting that, after a few months, ICG data eventually concords with the media data.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Main issue for me now is the delay between a death occurring, and it being confirmed by the International Crisis Group.  Deaths need to be "named and substantiated", as described on the ICG page, and this can be especially delayed in the case of PKK casualties. For July, Hurriyet, the Turkist newspaper with the largest circulation, reported about 52 PKK deaths, 5 civilian deaths, and 3 army deaths (based on an archive search).  This is essentially the same as the present (early September) ICG death count for July.  So in general, official sources appear to concord with the ICG counts.  (I really need to go back and compare months before July; add that to the to-do list ...) For August, Hurriyet reported a significant increase in deaths: 11 army, 7 civilian.  PKK casualties were reported as a total of 68 deaths to about the 19th, then the army changed their preferred term to "neutralised" (which combines deaths and captures).  106 total PKK deaths and "neutralisations" were reported in the Hurriyet for the month ... 106 + 11 + 7 = 124 ... which is _really_ close to the cut off. Anadolu Agency, a government-run news agency, reports 176 PKK deaths "inside and outside Turkey" due to "Turkey security forces' anti-terrorism operations":
http://aa.com.tr/en/info/infographic/6953 So what to make of the fact that Turkish official news sources (which usually are concordant with the ICG) have been reporting significant increases in PKK deaths for August, but the ICG has not?  Either Turkish sources are inflating death estimates where they have not previously, or else there is a serious lag in the ICG ability to confirm PKK deaths.  I strongly suspect the latter. Just for August, if we trust official data, it is likely that deaths exceeded 125.  It is not a certainty as the number of "neutralisations" or "deaths outside Turkey" cannot be teased out of the data I have.  Let's call it p= 0.75.  The next question: will the ICG be able to confirm those deaths before 29 December?  For August, I think that that is likely (p= 0.9).  However, in subsequent months it will become more difficult for the ICG to confirm PKK deaths before the end of December. Overall, I think is still highly likely that August will eventually pass the 125 threshold (68%). Casualties, definitionally and methodologically include both deaths and casualties.  ICG restricts the domain of actors to those killed and confirmed fatalities.  It excludes cases from its count that are unconfirmed.  This further restricts the domain of the two actors in conflict interactions: the Turkish state, its officers, police and other officials along with PKK insurgents and its proxies.  Turkey views the PKK as a terror group, while the PKK is engaged in a political and military struggle for independence.  Since the cessation of a relatively short period of conflict and an unsuccessful coup against the state, the two sets of actors have intensified their asymmetric non-zero-sum game of terror and counterterror.  Given this dynamic we should expect the counts to move above the threshold, however, restrictions on the range for counts in 4 groups will be reduced.  Depending on the military tactics employed by the PKK, and the constrained definitions in counting methods, this should reduce the total number of casualties counted by ICG.   Additional data sources would indicate support for crossing the threshold but the constraint explanation reasonably accounts for variances in actual versus the constrained casualties counted. Independent sources not linked to ICG indicate that 54 casualties have been counted up to August 21, 2017.  We should expect an estimated count of casualties that do not meet the IFP threshold of 125 because ICG exclude injured actors in the count.  Continued escalation of the Turkey-PKK conflict does not bode well for any level of stability in the country.   Changes in the political dynamics and the moves toward further autocratic strategies (including the mass levels of arrest, detention and torture) by the state, significant mobilization toward PKK sentiments and strategies will increase their organizational membership, insurgent training and resistance among the Kurdish population not currently engaged in insurgent activity with the PKK.  This could portend additional counts for ICG as a function of rebel engagement.  The likelihood of violent interactions among the actors will increase if the Kurdish indendence movements succeed in the drive for independence in late September.  If the independence referendum is cancelled or postponed to a future date, which recent rounds of talks indicate is also likely, then we can expect the number of violent interactions to decrease significantly.
